awd_titl_txt: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Support for the National Center for Atmospheric Research
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This report represents projects that are funded by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and awarded through the National Science Foundation (NSF) Cooperative Agreement to the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) for the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR). NCAR provided research and development activities for the Developmental Testbed Center (DTC) and supported efforts for the NOAA National Weather Service(NWS) Hurricane Forecast Improvement Project (HFIP). 

The DTC is a distributed facility with components located at NCAR and NOAA's Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRL). NCAR provided support in overall coordination of DTC activities and maintained strong ties with the community. Support included: overseeing and coordinating the annual planning process, conducting DTC workshops and tutorials, creating and maintaining the DTC website, code management and community support for NOAA's Unified Forecast System (UFS) Short-Range Weather (SRW) and Medium-Range Weather (MRW) Applications. NCAR also provided coordination for the DTC Visitor Program, development and community support for the Modeul Evaulation Tool (MET) and METViewer, and testing and evaluation that focused on the performance of atmospheric physics suites. The program supported visitors to work with the DTC to test new forecasting and verification techniques, models, and model components. NCAR research efforts have provided a successful program for the operational weather prediction centers with options for near-term advances in operational weather forecasting and Numerical Weather Prediction codes for researchers that represent the latest advances in technology.

This project provided the community with tools for modeling, verification, and data assimilation. These tools are supported through online documentation and tutorials, training videos, e-mail help responses, and posting to online forums.  All software packages are open source and available to the research community. 

New knowledge developed through this program has been shared with the community through presentations at various scientific conferences, as well as user workshops. Reports for all visitor projects have been posted on the DTC website. The research supported by this project has impacted the way that science is conducted by encouraging the sharing of ideas and methods through community code development.

NCAR research efforts supporting NOAA NWS primarily focused on developing new hurricane display and diagnostic capabilities to allow forecasters to more deeply examine the performance of operational and experimental models. Activities also supported further enhancements to the HFIP data service system to improve hurricane forecast accessibility for more in-depth diagnostic evaluations and enhancements to the National Hurricane Center(NHC) display and diagnostic system. Enhancements to the systems included improved stratification and historical best-track evaluation, additional methods to stratify and compute consensus hurricane track and intensity forecasts, and improved graphical display tools. These tools were integrated with the HFIP project website to provide improved accessibility to the HFIP community.

The new hurricane display and diagnostic capabilities allow forecasters and research scientists to more deeply examine the performance of operational and experimental models. The development of new display systems and verification methods to evaluate experimental tropical cyclone forecast systems provide tools to support the integration of new technology that will enhance the accuracy of hurricane forecasts. Improved hurricane forecast predictions lead to an improved warning of impacts such as storm surge, flooding, and extreme wind conditions. Verification and diagnostic methods developed on this project can be applied to the forecasting of other atmospheric phenomena such as mid-latitude cyclones, snow-bands, and other mesoscale features. The activities from this project have provided a structure for implementing numerical weather prediction, display and diagnostic system, data assimilation, and verification improvements from the research community that have improved NOAA's operational and research hurricane modeling systems. 

Results have been disseminated to the scientific community through presentations at conferences, project meetings, and HFIP telecons.  In addition, all results from testing and evaluation activities are available on the NOAA website. The NHC Display and Diagnostic system are available to the community through the project website and hurricane products are made available to the community through the HFIP Products website.
